sentence-detokenized: The EU rejects Germany's call to boycott British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
On Thursday, the European Commission said it disagreed with Germany's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb until scientists determine whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.

Germany's representative on the European Union's veterinary committee, Werner Zwingmann, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy sheep meat from countries other than Britain until scientific opinions become clearer.
"We do not support such a recommendation because we do not see any grounds for it", Commission chief spokesman Nicolaus van der Pas said at a briefing.
He said that further scientific research was needed and if action was found to be necessary, it should be taken by the European Union.

He said last month's proposal by European Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler to ban sheep marrow, spleen and spinal cord in the human and animal food chain was a very specific and precautionary measure to protect human health.
Fischler proposed EU-wide measures after the UK and France reported that sheep could become infected with bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), mad cow disease, under laboratory conditions.

But Fischler agreed to reconsider his proposal after the EU's Standing Veterinary Committee, which is made up of animal health officials, questioned whether such action was justified as there was only a small risk to human health.
Earlier, Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio accused Fischler at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers of causing unjustified alarm by "dangerous generalisation".
Only France and the UK backed Fischler's proposal.
Early next month, the EU's scientific veterinary and multidisciplinary committees are due to look again at the issue and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
Sheep have long been known to become infected with scrapie, a brain disorder similar to BSE, which is thought to have been transmitted to cattle via feed containing animal waste.

On Thursday, British farmers denied there was a danger to human health from their sheep, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could affect consumers across Europe.
"We need to be extremely careful about how other countries take their lead from Germany," John Lloyd Jones, chairman of the National Farmers Union in Wales, told BBC radio.

Bonn has led efforts to protect public health since consumer confidence plummeted in March after a British report showed that people can contract a disease similar to mad cow disease by eating contaminated beef.
Last year Germany imported 47 600 sheep from the UK, almost half of the total.
4,275 tonnes of British mutton were imported, accounting for around 10% of total imports.
A rare draft of a Hendrix song sold for nearly $17,000.
A rare early handwritten draft of a song by American guitar legend Jimi Hendrix was sold for nearly $17,000 on Thursday at an auction of some of the late musician's favorite possessions.
A Florida restaurant paid 10,925 pounds ($16,935) for a draft of the song "Ain't No Telling," which Hendrix wrote on stationery in a London hotel in late 1966.
At the end of his concert in the English city of Nottingham in January 1967, he threw leaves into the audience, where he was picked up by a fan.
The buyers also acquired 16 other items auctioned by Hendrix's ex-girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, who lived with him from 1966 to 1969.
Among them is a black lacquer and pearl-encrusted box used by Hendrix to store his drugs, which an anonymous Australian buyer purchased for 5,060 pounds ($7,845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970 at the age of 27.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the atmosphere for talks.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
On Thursday, China accused Taipei of spoiling the atmosphere for a resumption of cross-Strait talks with Taiwanese Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Ukraine this week, which angered Beijing.

Just a few hours after Chinese state media said the time had come to start political talks with Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofan told Reuters, "The Taiwanese authorities broke the necessary atmosphere to start negotiations. "
State media quoted China's chief negotiator with Taipei, Tang Shubei, as telling a Taiwanese group on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks.
"Now is the time for the two sides to begin political negotiations...
is to end the state of hostility," the overseas edition of People's Daily quoted Tang as saying on Thursday.

In an interview with Reuters television, Foreign Ministry spokesman Sheng said he had read reports of Tang's comments but gave no details on why the negotiator felt the time was right for talks with Taiwan, which Beijing considers a breakaway province.
China, which has long opposed all of Taipei's efforts to gain greater international recognition, was angered by Taiwan Vice President Lien's visit to Ukraine this week.
China says the time has come for negotiations with Taiwan.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China has said it is time for political talks with Taiwan and that the rival island must take practical steps to achieve that goal.

Consultations are to be held to determine the timing and format of the talks, the official Xinhua news agency reported late Wednesday, citing Tang Shubei, executive vice chairman of the Cross-Strait Relations Association.
Car registrations in Germany in July increased by 14.2 percentage points year-on-year.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
First registrations of motor vehicles in Germany rose 14.2 percent in July this year compared with a year earlier, the Federal Motor Vehicle Office said Thursday.
The office reported that 356,725 new vehicles were registered in July 1996 - 304,850 cars and 15,613 trucks.
These figures represent a 13.6% increase for passenger cars and a 2.2% decrease for trucks compared to July 1995.
Motorcycle registrations increased by 32.7% during the period.
The growth is partly due to an increased number of Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers say domestic demand is weak, the federal office said.
Almost all German carmakers saw an increase in registrations during the period.
Volkswagen AG won 77,719 registrations, just over a quarter of the total.
Opel AG together with General Motors ranked second with 49,269 registrations, representing 16.4% of the total.
In third place was Ford with 35,563 registrations, or 11.7%.
Only Seat and Porsche had fewer registrations in July 1996 compared to July last year.
Seat recorded 3,420 registrations compared to 5,522 registrations in July a year earlier.
Porsche registrations are down from 643 to 554.
GREEK SOCIALISTS GIVE THE GREEN LIGHT TO THE PRIME MINISTER FOR THE ELECTIONS.

The executive bureau of the Hellenic Socialist Party has given the green light to Prime Minister Costas Simitis to call early elections, the party's Secretary General Costas Skandalidis told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make an official statement after a cabinet meeting later on Thursday, Skandalidis said.

Port Conditions from Lloyds Shipping Intelligence Service --
LATAKIA, 10 August - The waiting time in Latakia and Tartus is currently 24 hours.
Israel downplays fears of war with Syria.
Colin Siegel
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
On Thursday, Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said the current tensions between the two countries looked like a storm in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israel's ambassador to Washington had been holding fruitless talks with Syria, told Israel Radio that Damascus seemed to want to talk, not fight.
"It seems to me that the Syrian priority is still to negotiate.
The Syrians are confused, they are definitely tense, but the general assessment here in Washington is that this is essentially a storm in a teacup," he said.
Rabinovic ends his term as ambassador.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elisar, a former Israeli envoy to Egypt and politician from the right-wing Likud party.
On Wednesday, Israel sent Syria a message through Washington saying it was committed to peace and wanted to start negotiations without preconditions.
But she blamed Damascus for creating a dangerous atmosphere.
On Wednesday, Syria accused Israel of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently test-fired a missile.
She said the weapons she purchased were for defensive purposes.

"The message we sent to (Syrian President Hafez al-) Assad is that Israel is ready at any time, without preconditions, to start peace talks," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy said in an interview with Israel Radio.
Tensions have been rising since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June vowing to preserve the Golan Heights, which Israel seized from Syria during the 1967 Middle East war.
Israeli-Syrian peace talks over the Golan have been deadlocked since 1991 despite the previous government's willingness to make concessions on the Golan.
The last peace talks between the two sides were held in February.
"The voices coming from Damascus are bad, not good.
The media...
are full of expressions and declarations that should be alarming...
this artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can become its prisoners," Levy says.
"We expect Syria, if its face is turned towards peace, to respond to Israel's message to start peace talks because that is our goal," he said. "
We don't want war, God forbid.
Nobody gains from wars. "
Israel's Channel Two television said Damascus had sent a "reassuring signal" to Israel.
He did not cite a source for the report.
Spokesmen for Netanyahu and Levy said they could not confirm it.
The TV station also reported that Netanyahu had sent messages to reassure Syria through Cairo, the US and Moscow.
Polish diplomat denies nurses are stranded in Libya.
On Thursday, a Polish diplomat denied a Polish tabloid report this week that Libya was denying exit visas to 100 Polish nurses trying to return home after working in the North African country.
"This is not true.

So far, we are not aware of any nurse being blocked or held in Libya without her will, and we have not received any complaints," Tadeusz Avdankiewicz, in charge of affairs at the Polish embassy in Tripoli, told Reuters by telephone.

Poland's labour ministry said this week it would send a team to Libya to investigate, but Avdankiewicz said the probe was prompted by complaints from some nurses about working conditions, such as non-payment of their wages.
He said there were about 800 Polish nurses working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iraq-based Iranian exile group pledged Thursday to provide support to Iranian Kurdish rebels after they were attacked by Iranian troops deep inside Iraq last month.

Mujahidin Khalq said in a statement that the organization's leader Massoud Rajavi met with the secretary general of the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran (KDPI), Hassan Rastegar, in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed his support for Iranian Kurdish rebels.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian resistance will continue to stand shoulder to shoulder with its Kurdish compatriots and the resistance movement in Iranian Kurdistan," the statement said.
A spokesman for the group said the meeting "signals a new level of cooperation between Mujahedin-e Khalq and the Iranian Kurdish opposition".
In July, Iran bombed targets in northern Iraq intensively, hunting down KDP guerrillas based in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside the control of the government in Baghdad.
Iraqi Kurdish areas bordering Iran are under the control of guerrillas from the Iraqi Kurdish group Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK).
The PUK and the Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), the two main factions of Iraqi Kurds, have controlled northern Iraq since Iraqi forces were pushed out of Kuwait during the 1991 Gulf War.
Clashes erupted over the weekend between the two sides, the most serious since the US-sponsored ceasefire signed last year.
Mujahidin Khalq said Iranian troops had shelled KDP positions in the Qasri district of Suleymaniyah province, near the Iranian border, over the past two days.
He said about 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey are launching air and ground strikes against targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of their own Kurdish rebels.
US-led air forces in southern Turkey defend Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by Baghdad forces.
The Saudi riyal exchange rate is stable in the calm summer trade.
Dealers in the kingdom said the Saudi riyal spot rate against the dollar and interest rates on interbank riyal deposits were mostly stable this week amid quiet summer trading.
"There have been no changes in the Saudi riyal exchange rate.
The market was very quiet because of the summer holidays," says one trader.
The spot rate for the rial was 3,7504/06 per dollar.
One-month interbank deposits were at 5-1/2, 3/8%, three-months at 5-5/8, 1/2%, and six-months at 5-3/4, 5/8%.
One-year funds were at 6, 5-7/8%.
Israel approves Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel on Thursday gave Palestinian President Yasser Arafat permission to fly over its territory to the West Bank, ending a brief crisis between Israel and the PLO, an aide to Arafat said.
"The problem is closed.
The president's plane has been cleared to pass through Israeli airspace, but the president is not expected to travel to the West Bank before Monday," Nabil Abu Rdaina told Reuters.

Arafat was due to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Thursday, but the meeting venue was changed to Gaza after Israel refused permission for the Palestinian leader's helicopters to fly.
Palestinian officials accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to stop the Ramallah meeting by keeping Arafat on the ground.
Arafat subsequently cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO civil affairs officials on the Allenby Bridge between Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdaina said Arafat decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday after Israel lifted the ban because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not have been free until Monday.
Arafat to meet Peres in Gaza after no-fly zone.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday after Palestinians said the right-wing Israeli government had banned the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank for talks with the former prime minister.

Japanese Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said at a press conference on Wednesday that he believes the Bank of Japan's (BoJ) policy on interest rates, aimed at ensuring economic growth, has not changed since the publication of the central bank's "tankan" survey.
